awd_titl_txt: Similarity as a process model of intertemporal choice
awd_abstract_narration:
Intertemporal choices are ones between receiving one benefit sooner or receiving a larger benefit later. These types of decisions are ubiquitous both for humans and animals and there are striking parallels between intertemporal decisions across species in terms of impulsivity.  The ?similarity? model of choice, a relatively new approach to understanding decision making in humans, provides a cognitive and procedural mechanism whereby choices are made. The objective of this project is to determine whether this model can apply to animals and, specifically, to three species of jays. Understanding intertemporal choice in animals will allow us to investigate aspects of impulsivity that are not easy to test in humans and will yield insights into how and why humans make decisions in the way that they do. Intertemporal choices underlie some of the most pressing problems facing society from obesity to inadequate investment in retirement. Understanding the mechanisms underlying these choices can help people make better decisions by focusing their attention on the long-term benefits of a healthy lifestyle or a secure financial future.

The overarching objective of the project is to unify the study of intertemporal choice across humans and animals by applying a model developed for humans to other species. Specific goals are to (1) develop and validate an index of similarity in animals, (2) extend the similarity model of intertemporal choice to animals in foraging and social tasks, and (3) develop a general similarity model by including continuous similarity judgments. This project will provide the first test of a new class of models of intertemporal choice in animals, the first measurement and comparison of the similarity construct across different animal species, and the first test of similarity models across decision domains, thus improving our understanding of decision making and having critical implications for a range of fields. It also addresses the societal goals of providing research opportunities for a diverse range of undergraduates and involving the public in science through the development of software to engage and educate.

por.por_cntn:
Every decision that humans and other animals make is an intertemporal choice between reward amounts available at different time delays. For over 75 years, the temporal discounting approach has dominated the economic, psychological, and biological study of intertemporal choice for both humans and other species. This approach proposes that individuals devalue future options. But this approach does not specify the exact cognitive steps that an individual would go through to make a choice. The goal of the research was to test an alternative to discounting, namely, the similarity model. Rather than devaluing reward amounts, the similarity model compares reward amounts and time delays based on their similarity (Are $100 and $105 similar or dissimilar? Is waiting 1 day vs. 4 days similar or dissimilar?). The similarity model can outperform discounting in predicting intertemporal choices in humans, but it has not been tested in other species. Our approach measures similarity and its effects on intertemporal choice in foraging and social preference tasks in other species (pinyon jays---Gymnorhinus cyanocephalus) to determine whether it offers a general model of intertemporal choice. We also aim to expand the similarity model from simple, binary similar/dissimilar judgments to more continuous measures of how similar reward amounts and time delays are.

Our project accomplished a number of key scientific objectives. First, using machine-learning algorithms, we replicated our previous work demonstrating that the numerical difference (e.g., 4-1=3) and the numerical ratio (e.g., 1/4=0.25) for pairs of numbers predict people's similarity judgments. That is, people consider number pairs with large differences and small ratio to be more similar than small differences and large ratios.  Second, we explored different methodological approaches to measuring similarity judgments in humans. We discovered that (1) we can predict judgments with 88% accuracy with only 15 different numerical pairs, (2) offering questions sequentially or simultaneously did not influence judgments, (3) for the same numerical pair, asking for a binary judgment (similar/dissimilar) produces lower ratings of similarity than asking for a continuous judgment (how similar from 0-9). Third, like binary judgments, continuous judgments of similarity were predicted by numerical difference and numerical ratio. However, intertemporal choices were better predicted by other models than similarity judgments. Fourth, we used numerical preference tasks as a proxy for similarity judgments in pinyon jays. We tested them both with a food task (e.g., choosing to eat 2 vs. 3 treats) and a social task (e.g., choosing to sit next to a group of 2 or 3 other birds). For the food task, numerical difference and numerical ratio predicted their choices but not independently, as seen in the human data. For the social task, neither difference nor ratio predicted choices, highlighting that how animals make these judgments depends on the context of the situation.

In addition to achieving these scientific goals, this project also had broader impacts in training, hardware/software resources, and science communication. This project helped 18 undergraduate students, 5 graduate students, and 4 lab technicians at University of Nebraska-Lincoln gain experience in computer programming, experimental design, hardware design, animal research, public outreach, systematic review and meta-analysis, and the scientific process more generally. We also provide benefits to the research community not only by publishing and presenting our work for scholars in our fields (10 publications, 7 conference presentations) but also by openly publishing plans for building treat dispensers from commercially available pet feeders or by using a 3D printer, thereby allowing other researchers or do-it-yourselfers the opportunity to adapt these technologies for their own needs. Given the current lack of automated treat dispensers on the market, this could provide a low-cost technology that any animal researchers could use for their research. In addition, we developed and made public two open-source software packages for the R statistical software system. One package facilitates data cleaning from datasets generated by online survey systems. The other develops flashcards to help students learn how to use R. Finally, this project has impacted the general public through an outreach event at the Nebraska State Natural History Museum. We organized an event that attracted over 200 visitors to learn about animal behavior and the role that impulsivity plays in their lives.
